A few years ago the Nobel Memorial Prize for Economics was awarded for demonstrating concepts of thermodynamics apply to economic systems.  I'm sure economists were grateful because, gee, how could economics not be a science if the concepts of thermodynamics apply to it, right?   Thermodynamics.  Temperature, enthalpy, entropy.  Turn it upside down and what do you get?  Statistical mechanics.  Thermodynamics starts with huge quantities of phenomena and measures bulk properties like the aforementioned temperature.  Statistical mechanics starts with small numbers and extrapolates up to bulk properties.  They end up at the same place approaching from different directions.  If one builds up to thermodynamics from statistical dynamics, it is pretty clear probability underlies all thermodynamic properties. If thermodynamics works in economics, probability plays a bigger factor in economics than almost any economist gives credit, certainly more than an adherent to the Austrian School or a strict monetarist would.  In fact, running away from probabilistic models is what carried so many Keynesians to monetarism in the seventies and eighties in the first place. But there is a bigger problem here: probability is about distributions.  If thermodynamics and probability are important to economics being a science, then distribution is important to economics being a science.  Why then does economics make it clear that distribution is not a part of what economics is about?  If economics is a science it must in part be about distribution.  But as any economist will religiously recite, economics does not include distribution. If economics were a science, it would. Many economists, perhaps most, are involved in econometrics, which has its own problems quite beyond foundational, using mathematical technique to substitute for insight.  Think, for example, of Herbert Stein and his curve-fitting embarrassment. Mathematics is the language of science and economics bristles with mathematics.  But mathematics doesn't in and of itself make economics a science.  The problem is too often that the mathematics may be invested with meaning and emotional values beyond which it can reasonably bear.   If you go back to that last paragraph and substitute the word "astrology" for the word "economics" at every instance, you would see how much economics and astrology have in common.  Is astrology a science? If you go outside your house on a summer's day and drop a hard rubber ball from shoulder height onto a concrete surface, any physicist would tell you the ball would bounce.  If we did a similar thing in terms of economic theory, one economist would say yes, the ball would bounce, another might claim the ball would stop dead as soon as it hit the cement, a third would say the ball might not fall at all, it might simply drift away on the breeze.  Most economists would start by saying, "On the one hand..." Moreover, there are serious and deep problems in falsifiability in economics as it is practiced that are seldom acknowledged and never addressed.  I can certainly understand in this day and age the desire to regard economics as a science.  I can certainly understand the knee-jerk tendency to defend it as a science.  But economics as practiced and taught today is more like alchemy than chemistry. Economics is at once the most mathematical and least scientific of the social sciences--that is, unless you are counting astrology as a social science.  What I think economics most closely resembles is alchemy.  Some alchemists were clearly doing science.  Some clearly were not.  I think that is also true of economics: some economists do science, most pursue programs defined by adherence to schools of thought which are necessarily flawed and do not. And don't minimize economics refusal to consider distribution.  In a science where the laws of thermodynamics apply, doctrinally refusing to consider distribution is like trying to predict the weather without considering the effects of wind.   Can you do it?  Well, sporadically, yes.  And with caveats (on the one hand...), even more.  But is it then a science?  Is it scientific to prohibit consideration of a clearly pertinent perameter? The practitioners of economics at once eschew the practice of science but claim its mantle.  Saying economics is science because it involves a lot of mathematics is like saying a phone book is literature because it uses a lot of words. I wish economics were a science.  It would benefit us all.  But it yet is not and I can't see it becoming a science any time soon.

I think the easiest way to answer this question is not to attempt to define science (which is really really hard) and then show that economics fits that definition, but to attempt to construct a definition of science that excludes only economics while keeping other sciences as 'science'. I think any such attempt will fail. As a simple example, many people seem to think that science necessarily involves experiments. It's easy to see that as a historical matter, this is false. The earliest science was done by astronomers, like Kepler, who, of course, could run no experiments on the stars, but instead just worked to keep really accurate measurements of where the stars and planets were at particular times. The idea that Copernicus/Galileo/Kepler weren't doing science when they just recorded planetary positions is laughable: their theories about the planets are, of course, at the base of the entire scientific tradition. Further, even today there are sciences (astronomy, geology, meteorology, ecology) where most of the most important hypotheses are not amenable to experiments. The Nobel Prize for Physics just went to the folks who first noticed that the Universe is expanding at an accelerating rate. This was done purely using observational (non-experimental) data. Similarly, many folks seem to think that economics isn't a science because many of its practitioners are blinded by political ideology. But, of course, scientists in all fields are blinded by personal preferences, sometimes including political ideology when their research touches on ideological topics. Another example: some claim that economists often derive things from first principles as though they were studying math rather than carrying out empirical investigations. But fields that include both individuals doing empirical work and other individuals doing thinking from first principles are common. Evolutionary biologists often use game theory to make predictive theories. Einstein imagined himself inside a beam of light in order to come up with theories of relativity and never did run any experiments to prove his theory, etc. etc. Healthy fields have theoreticians as well as applied researchers. Some suggest that economics cannot be a science because it has normative components. Actually, economists work very hard to separate the normative and positive parts of economics, with only the latter considered to be the major object of study. Unless what is meant is that all sciences smuggle in normative assumptions, in which case that's a criticism of science, not a demarcation criterion for what counts as science. Others think economics is not a science because it relies on poor assumptions, like rational behavior. There are two obvious responses: 1) economists working in areas that don't make assumptions about rational behavior are now extremely common with the rise of behavioral economics, institutional economics, etc. and 2) this confuses whether economics as a field is a science and whether economics right now is any good. Imagine declaring that Galileo was not a scientist because his theories had low predictive power! They did, indeed have low predictive power, but that's because physics and astronomy were young sciences, not because they were unscientific! To sum up: a lot of times, people mentally equate 'science' and 'physics' as though experimental physics were THE perfect, paradigmatic science. Once you've made that mistake, it's easy to argue that economics isn't scientific: it's not particularly like physics! But in fact, science is just hugely diverse, and it's very difficult to explain why economists are non-scientific if folks in fields like astronomy and evolutionary biology are in fact paradigmatically scientific.

Short answer: Yes. A popular view in epistemology is that a field of study is a science if it makes "falsifiable" claims. A claim is falsifiable if we can use it to make concrete predictions about the world, and then observe the result of those predictions. The classic example of a falsifiable theory is the theory of gravity: it claims -- among other things -- that if we hold an object in the air near the Earth's surface and drop it in a vacuum, it will fall with an acceleration of roughly 9.8 m/s^2. We can pick up objects, drop them and measure their acceleration as they fall. Every time we do so and fail to observe a contradiction of the claim, it strengthens our trust in the theory. If, however, we find that objects stop falling at the predicted acceleration, then we have to hold the theory -- or its assumptions -- in doubt. Economics makes falsifiable claims about the world, although it's often difficult to find "natural experiments" where only one economic variable changes at a time. For instance, economics predicts that -- all other things being equal -- a rise in the minimum wage will lead to a rise in unemployment. If we could visit an island and, keeping all other things equal, raise the minimum wage, we could check whether unemployment went up or down as a result, so the claim is technically falsifiable. Economists can't conduct such experiments, however, so they have to wait for situations like that, or close to that, to happen naturally and then use statistical techniques to unravel the effects of the wage hike. Other examples of falsifiable claims from economics include: Increasing the money supply will increase inflation.Raising the price of a normal good will cause the quantity consumed to decrease.Capping rents will decrease the quantity of rental housing available.We can, in theory at least, construct experiments in which we can observe whether or not these claims are contradicted by reality.

Ah, an excellent question. There is much literature to be read on the topic, and I personally like Mankiw's view that economists can be both scientists and "engineers." First, we must accept that if economics is a science, it is a social science. That means that the hard-and-fast laws of physics and chemistry will almost never be found in economics. However, if we define "science" as the systematic study of the world around us, in which we draw conclusions based on our observations, then economics is certainly a science. That is exactly what economists do. They collect data, run some analyses, and try to draw conclusions. Of course, some economists specialize in theoretical model building as opposed to data analysis, but this practice is being replaced more and more by data work. Now, why do economists fight so much? I think that that is a very interesting question with several dimensions of answers. First, as Paul Krugman has said, while economics is a science, economists often do not behave like scientists. The objectivity of the economist is often compromised because of his political or moral beliefs. If you're a strong liberal, you're more likely to dismiss a study that shows that taxing the rich slows economic growth. If you're a strong conservative, you're likely to scoff at studies that show that Obamacare has decreased the rate of the uninsured.  It's not really surprising that economists fight more than the natural scientists. Does the discovery of a new biochemical process speak to your moral and political world-view, the values that you were probably raised on since birth? It's unlikely, so biochemists don't have as much of a reason to fight because they can be much more objective. Does the discovery that debt levels upwards of 100% of gdp have no affect on economic growth speak to your moral and political world-view, the values that you were probably raised on since birth? It's very likely, so a lot of objectivity is lost. Also, the social sciences are so complex that when you want to explain changes in variables, so many factors affect those variables that it's difficult to say with certainty what causes those changes.

To be scientifically rigorous, would require a duplicate identical earth (or at identical economy) with which a single parameter can be uniquely altered so as to observe the difference in result. In this way, on can attribute any difference in observation uniquely to that parameter. But, since this is not possible to so validate as with the “hard sciences” (which is why they are called “hard sciences”) it is often referred to as a “soft science”. The further problem is that people will try to dismiss the conclusions of the science of economics they don’t like because of that. Just because it cannot be rigorously tested, don’t prove it is wrong. For example, people will claim that the economic limitations implied by principles of market supply and demand pricing are just “philosophy” means you can just disregard them at will anytime they obstruct something you would like to believe to be true. Well, there are some things that have been so thoroughly studied and analysed, both logically and observationally, that they are held to be as incontrovertibly valid (until proven otherwise) the same as any other law of nature. Principles of market supply and demand pricing are held to be a correct predictor of observational outcomes. The principle of market supply and demand pricing is often dismissed with a false hand-waving such as “well, we didn’t observe exactly the outcome predicted in instance X”. But there are two problems here. One is, well, therein lies the problem - since you can’t restrict or limit changes to a single parameter, you also cannot claim a failure to observe some exact outcome as proof that principles of market supply and demand don’t hold or didn’t hold. They may have been (and is likely the case) that there were also other countervailing factors present. A simple illustration is a plane in flight. Does that somehow prove that gravity doesn’t always apply because the plane didn’t fall from the sky? No. gravity still applies to that airplane, it is just that there is also a force of lift that acts in opposition to gravity. If that countervailing force were to be removed, if the wings fall off or the helicopter blades stop spinning, we all know what the outcome will be as predicted by gravity. And that’s also a useful illustration. Gravity ultimately wins when you can no longer generate lift. Similarly, supply and demand ultimately wins when you run out of whatever it is that is seemingly causing supply and demand to not apply. Another example I like to illustrate this common fallacy: fill a sink half-way. Now, open the drain and turn on the faucet at the same time. What will happen? Well, the sink will probably empty (unless the drain is clogged). Does that somehow mean that the faucet doesn’t fill the sink or that the faucet even causes the sink to drain? Of course not. It’s just that the action of the drain more than offsets the effect of the faucet. And if an objective is to drain the sink, does that mean that we should turn on the faucet to obtain that outcome, or that turning on the faucet is not counterproductive to obtaining that outcome? No, of course not. But there are those who will try to make such an argument in matters of economics. Just because we cannot rigorously test the theory, doesn't mean that we can’t know the effects and consequences. Even though we cannot perform the follow test in economics doesn’t mean we don’t know with near certitude the answer: if we could time two different cases - one with the faucet on and one with the faucet off - will there be no difference in times or will there be a difference and in which way? So which one is closer to science and which is further from science: to claim that the faucet will adversely slow the desired draining process as opposed to a faster draining time without the faucet on; or to claim we should go ahead and open the faucet too, because obviously, having the faucet on doesn’t keep the sink from draining and therefore has no adverse effects on draining the sink.

Perhaps interestingly, the mathematical, and thereby rational, basis for Science as a way-to-go-about-in-this-world lies in Econometrics, a field which initially began as an exploration of empiricism in Economics. Science is simply the collection of correlations of datasets, under the assumptions of regression (nothing more, nothing less). The inferences that we draw from the correlation and significant coefficients of the regression are due to precise theorems in mathematics. Ultimately, all natural sciences are (only ?) supported by R-squares of close to 1.00 and highly significant coefficients. Infact, even causality is not a requirement for science; only precise definition of variables involved (which often passes off as causality) is required. Economics follows the standards required of any of the other sciences. The only problem is that there are far too many variables, some of them difficult to define and/or measure, in the real world to get high R-squares. Hence, several opposing economic theories can be held true at the same time, since both have the same/similar evidence, or rather, evidence of the same/similar strength, which is why economists have difficulty in coming to a consensus. I am reasonably confident that a similar lack of consensus would exist in physics had there been 1000 different, difficult to distinguish, types of quarks. To conclude, Yes, Economics is a Science.(And that's why, I would assume, that the Nobel Prize is justified) Edit 1: Several people point out the inability to conduct experiments under lab conditions as a deficiency for economics as a science. In mathematical terms, it translates to a trust in/on lab conditions to create a) exogenous independent variables (an assumption of regression for valid inference), b) large number of observations for central limit theorems to hold and c) ceteris paribus conditions. Regarding argument a): This argument is valid if there was some way to know for sure if the (lab - controlled) independent variables are indeed exogenous. However, such 'truth' is unavailable in the real world. Indeed, it is always an intuitive assumption that scientists make when they assume that some variables are exogenous. Economists make a similar kind of assumption regarding several economic variables and their exogeneity. As expected of the class of assumptions, some of them are not true. If in the course of research, when one feels that a particular assumption of exogeneity is possibly not true, the researcher tries a new line of research, and that's how science goes on. Regarding arguments b) and c): These are possible criticisms against economics. However, there are some economic questions for which large number of observations have been recorded. The probable core issue is that the time (as normally defined) taken to get many observations in economics is generally a lot and hence, several variables, which are not under study, change i.e. it is difficult to expect ceteris paribus even if the economist assumes it. The solution is to include every variable that can affect the dependent variable into the study, but as mentioned before, this would require a regression (and consequent analysis) of several hundreds, maybe thousands, of variables, which is a very difficult task for homo sapiens. Hence, economists apply intuition (and theory) and make do with available and potentially useful variables. This reduces the strength of the evidence but as mentioned before, for those of us who think that science is the only way-to-go-about-in-this-world and have an interest in economics, we might as well do something, even if it means getting slightly less strong results when compared to physics. Edit 2: It may look like I am redefining Science to suit my answer. My definition, I admit, is not one that is available in textbooks. But, in my opinion, my definition is one of the simplest ways to precisely define Science. Any other definition will require more assumptions on the world than the bare minimum ones. By the bare minimum assumptions, I am referring to the assumptions that allow for consistency in mathematics (Peano's Axioms). Hence, I request everyone to consider my definition; and after consideration, if you think it is incorrect, I request you to point me in the right direction. Edit 3: Perhaps I should provide an example to strengthen my case. Lets take Astrology. For the moment, let us assume that astrologers are able to provide precise and unambiguous definitions to the variables involved. For instance, say distances and angles of Jupiter from Earth (as explanatory variables) and outcomes of World Cup cricket matches (as dependent variables). For the moment, please also ignore the protests regarding causality that are being issued by the brain. Now, supposing an appropriate regression with the above variables gives an R-square of close to 1.00 with extremely significant slopes, mathematically, astrology has the same level of predictability as any theory in physics (Indeed, theories in Physics are backed by exactly these kinds of significant slopes and R-squares). In other words, even if we can't fathom the causal relationship, we would be wrong to ignore the results of this regression. It could be that some assumption of regression (such as exogeneity) is not really true and hence has resulted in such counter-intuitive results, in which case, it is upto to us to come up with a consensus on the issue. But under the assumptions of regression, the results do form a part of 'Science' even if they do not fit into our normal, everyday experience. Hence, defining Science as a 'collection of correlations of datasets under the assumptions of regression' is in my opinion a good definition. Thus, if astrology could be as precise, definition-wise, as other sciences, and if the results were as strong as physics, then astrology would be a science at par with physics, even if no causal mechanism is fathomable. The main issue is that astrologers don't provide precise definitions of variables. If such definitions are presented, then the regression results, if any good, will automatically lend credence to astrology with no further requirement of arguments (in which event, only a debate regarding the regression would go on for a long time till astrology becomes acceptable to society)  (A side point I wish to make is that 'Physics' or rather physicists generally stake claim when R-squares of close to 1.oo and highly significant slopes are reported. Indeed, this is how physicists would define 'physics' i.e. if some non-trivial regression failed to get an R-square very, very close to 1.00, irrespective of the significance of coefficients, physicists would not accept that regression as part of 'physics', though the regression is still a part of 'science') Also interestingly, the existence of causality is an assumption on the world, one which is entirely unnecessary for Science. Indeed, the truth value of the existence of causality cannot be known i.e. as stated before, such 'truth' is unavailable. Falsifiability: Several people point out falsifiability i.e. the possibility of finding insignificant evidence as a requirement for science. For me, it simply translates into the ability to come up with precise and unambiguous definitions for variables. However, it could be that I'm slightly wrong here and would be grateful if somebody could point out what the exact difference, results-wise, between proper definition of variables and falsifiability is. Edit 4: Perhaps, another interesting thought experiment is to imagine a world where, somehow, the best R-square possible was only 0.60 and not 1.00. This means that the very best of the physical 'laws' 'work' in the manner that we relate to only 60% of the time. Now, in such a world, our instinct to assign causal mechanisms would not work since causal mechanisms require logical absolutes/truths. However, would we be expected to sit around and do nothing in such a world? Obviously, we would make do with 0.6 and we would have a version of science in this world where the 0.6-ers are called physicists. The definition of science would still hold in this world, since this definition draws only from the consistency of mathematics. There are other solutions offered to avoid such situations such as probabilistic causation etc., but I think it is much better to dispense with the assumption of causation. It is important, hence, I reiterate. Causation is an assumption on the world and is unnecessary for science. Our consensus on the world would not change even if the assumption of causation were completely ignored in discussion, since it was never a part of the method of science. If you go by the widely accepted Popperian criterion of a science as a field centered upon falsifiability, then economics, is a science (a social science), albeit an imprecise one. A statement/theory/hypothesis is falsifiable if it is possible to conceive of an observation or an argument which negates the statement in question (i.e. if it can be proved false). But the problem of economics as a soft science lies in the problem of theorizing about a complex system whose details differ from country to country, and from time to time within the same country - i.e. a complex system that is dynamic and in flux. So as with Len Gould’s example, why economists may produce different policy prescriptions is that they base them on different theories. Due to the complexity of economies, multiple theories may be logically valid simultaneously, but their applicability contingent on a range of factors and variables which are not considered in the model/theory, but rather universalized. This is a problem I have come to observe in the discipline. So whilst trickle down theory and tax increase to reduce the deficit may both be logically sound per se, their formulations neglect to consider under what conditions each of the prescriptions is likely to work (e.g. spending patterns of those who benefit most from tax cuts, the current level of taxes & likelihood of disincentivizing tax avoidance and evasion; domestic profitability of investment, historical responsiveness of investment to tax reductions, etc.). It is this tendency for theoretical universality that economics is prone to ‘cycles of conventional wisdom’ (as Paul Krugman puts it) - whereby a conventional theory, after a period of domination, is accused of being ‘wrong’ because it seems to no longer be applicable to new times or data; when in reality the underlying facilitating conditions have only changed. So you will find different economists holding different theories that seemingly compete with each other on a universalistic basis, but if more rigourous, more nuanced analysis is undertaken, one would find that each theory is applicable given a set of facilitating conditions. So, as Dani Rodrik & Mark Rosenzweig say, it is not a simple question of ‘does it work?’, but ‘when does it work and when not and why?’ Even though modern economics emphasizes the use of empirical observation and analysis (e.g. econometrics) to attempt to refute an economic theory such that it conforms in this sense to falsifiability, problems at the theoretical level exist and persist to make the discipline lack consensus. This is not to say that even at the empirical level there are no problems. There are limits to econometric analysis, and one has to be creative and dynamic when using it to investigate a theory’s ‘validity’. For instance, an economist may simply want to test that X causes Y. Then a simple regression analysis is conducted to show this. The result is either X does cause Y, or X does not cause Y. By limiting the empirical analysis to such one-dimensional logic, the problem of theoretical universality manifests empirically. Better economists try to use different specifications, assess why certain cross-sections lie outside the relationship, if the relationship is stable over time, and what causes variations in the relationship across cross-sections and time, etc. Better economists also delve into individual cross-sections (e.g. countries) and gain knowledge of peculiar features that shape variable relationships, etc. But what is rife within the daily empirical literature is one-dimensional analyses which produce answers of yes/no to theories without conditionalities and nuance.

There are essentially four branches of academics: Natural sciences, which (I'm quoting Wikipedia) "are branches of science that seek to elucidate the rules that govern the natural world by using empirical and scientific methods." Examples include physics, biology, astronomy, and chemistrySocial sciences, which includes everything from anthropology to psychology to political science to, yes, economics.Formal sciences, such as mathematics, logic, and computer science, which deal primarily with a priori rather than a posteriori knowledge.Humanities, which (again quoting Wikipedia) "are academic disciplines that study the human condition, using methods that are primarily analytical, critical, or speculative, as distinguished from the mainly empirical approaches of the natural sciences."The first three of these all fall under the umbrella term "science," even though they use very different methods. So, by definition, economics is a science. There is a common perception of a "scientist" being someone in a white coat working in a laboratory using the scientific method, something not uncommon in the natural sciences. But that doesn't mean that that's the only, or the "real" type of science. Arguing that economics is not a science is tantamount to arguing that all the social sciences (and perhaps the formal sciences) are not science. Unfortunately, that quickly devolves into a semantic argument, trying to say that "science" means something different from the common definition (including natural, social, and formal sciences). It's easy to (and most academics would) argue that economics is not a natural science, but there's more to science than natural science.

Economics is absolutely a scientific subject. For every action, means are used to obtain ends. Because of that fact, we have the science of scarcity of means. Unfortunately, though, it's difficult for me to say that economists in general are scientists. Some are, and some are not. If someone tells me they can create long-lasting prosperity by increasing the supply of the money unit, which is only an indexing tool we use to perform accounting, then no, that's absurd. Money is a medium of exchange, and is scarce only because those things you exchange it for are scarce. If someone's going to tell me that their quantitative model of our real economy is at an equilibrium, and the actors within it have rational expectations, and they're going to "prove" something with that, then no, that's absurd. In that case, they'd be better served ditching utility functions and passing all the input data through an unsupervised learning algorithm, like a neural network, and seeing the output. I'd trust random weights over biased ones. For the reason that an economist, with one political ideology, can use some data to "prove" one thing, and another economist, with another political ideology, can use that same data again to "prove" another thing, is unscientistic behavior, but we shouldn't reject economics as a science because its practitioners are as biased as the rest of us— we should seek to develop methods to reduce bias.

Now under a positivist theory that must be a falsifiable statement. There would, therefore, have to be an experiment to “test” this. This is very laughable to normal people because the fact that “humans act” is a very self evident point, not to mention how would you even design an experiment to test that? Now to someone who uses the logical deductive method (the correct scientific method for economics), this is a very easy problem. I am acting by asserting that “humans act”. If a positivist (or any other crazy person) were to deny this they would be committing a contradiction because by denying this they would, of course, be acting.  To use a less cheeky example lets take the concept of exchange (commerce) between individuals, a very fundamental law of economics. You have two individuals, person A and person B. Person A will trade with Person B ONLY if Person A perceives that the thing he is going to give up is worth less than what he is going to receive. Person B must think likewise of the thing he is going to trade. Only if each individual thinks this will the trade be made. EXAMPLE: John has apples and Peter has wheat, and they want to trade. John must believe that the apples he is going to give away are worth less than the wheat he is going to receive and Peter must think that the wheat is going to give away is worth less than the apples he is going to receive. Each individual values the other’s trade good more than he values his own. ONLY then will the trade be made. NOW, if you are a positivist (and you believe that every statement is falsifiable) then this is not necessarily true. You would have to test this phenomena in order to see if it is true or not (again how do you even test this?) and even then it would only be tentatively true because, remember, every statement no matter how obvious, is falsifiable. Again to the normal person this is ridiculous, after using a bit of logic we can clearly see and grasp that the law of exchange is a true law. Now this isn’t just trivial theorizing here is what positivism implies in reality. Take for example Communism, which, by any objective standard, was a miserable failure. To a positivist, the statement I just made is, again, falsifiable, and forever will be, no matter how many times communism fails and kills people (you would think 100+ million deaths in dozens of examples would be enough to prove something). Always, the positivist will say “well if we just had of had Trotsky instead of Stalin” or “well government intervention didn’t work this time but that’s because of excuse A or excuse B”. It is evident then, that positivism, as it pertains to human action, really isn’t concerned with empirical reality, rather it uses the veneer of empiricism to justify any economically dogmatic belief, however untenable (things like the minimum wage, price controls, welfare, tariffs, central banking, etc.), on the grounds that since there must be perpetual testing of an assertion (because it’s falsifiable), we cannot throw out any theory or assertion. This is why one of the “great” positivist economists Paul Krugman, is able to make such blindly stupid assertions about the joys of state run healthcare such as “(The VA) has been highly successful in containing costs, yet provides excellent care”. After many exmaples of “VA”-like healthcare debacles around the world a logical person would begin to seriously question the validity of such systems. Not the positivist! “The VA (or NHS, or any socialized system) is mismanaged” they say! “If we just had the right people…..”. Nonsense. So the correct way to look at economics then is through deductive reasoning. Through certain basic and logical laws of praxeology (the study of human action) such as the law of marginal utility, exchange, and action, etc. We can begin to deduct, from those original basic assertions, more complex conclusions such as the cause of boom and bust cycles, the cause of wealth inequality, the nature of inflation, etc. Economics as a science is far more akin to applied logic (used in computer science for example) than it is to positive sciences such as physics. The human element is what makes the difference because humans, in spite of some natural impulses, are fundamentally LOGICAL. Therefore, a scientific method based on logic is all too fitting.

When I was at school, the main economics textbook was called “Positive Economics” by Richard Lipsey. The “Positive” part was meant to distinguish it from “normative”: it studied what is, rather than what should be. Economics would love to be a science. Economists do lots of hard mathematics, just like physicists, and they think they should get the same intellectual respect as the physicists. The problem is that physics has an experimental side and a theoretical side, and they work together. The experimental physicists have lots of kudos because they have big expensive kit to do their experiments with. So while theoretical physicists do quite often veer some way from what is practically observable (string theory?) they are anchored in reality - and in the academic pecking order, they are very much lower down the food chain than the experimentalists with their billion dollar budgets. Economics is very hard to measure. The theory depends on the existence of things called “rational actors”, which are approximations to reality in the same way as particles are approximations to reality in physics. But while electrons and protons can be observed behaving in a way that supports the particle model well enough, no one has yet observed a rational actor. And rational actors are supposed to be people and companies. People, on the whole, aren’t rational much. The assumption that they are is the foundation for most modern economics and economists continue to write papers and make predictions based on this unsupported assumption. As we say in computing, garbage in, garbage out, and I think that is the case for almost all papers based on mathematical economics published in the last thirty years. Modern economics, as taught in today’s universities, is the emperor’s new clothes. There is a new school of economics, post-crash economics, started by a group of students at Manchester University in 2009 who questioned what they were being taught as it had just been found badly wanting. But we fall back on the measurement problem. There is a whole branch of economics, econometrics, devoted to measuring economic factors. If the physics parallel were apt, the econometricians would have the equivalent respect (and budgets) of the experimental physicists. They would be the top dogs in the departments. But they are considered the nerdy geeks, while the theoretical economists get the top jobs and the hottest research students. However, I think there is an answer to the measurement problem. There is a huge amount of data - real-time transaction data - which the cashless society generates. It is, however, proprietary to the banks and in its raw form is personally-identifiable data subject to data protection. Appropriately anonymised, the potential for using this real-time data to support a new form of real-time econometrics could revolutionise the academic study of economics. But there are quite a few institutional hurdles to overcome before this will be possible.

Some aspects of it almost becomes applied physics or engineering, namely the ways that the foundations of the economy in terms of energy and resource availability, energy supply, and technological level impact the productivity of the economy. Other aspects of economics it’s very fuzzy and qualitative and ideological. This unevenness exists probably for a few reasons. 1.      First, since it’s a relatively young science. All sciences have gone through a sort of arc, where they started as branches of philosophy, then became separate subjects, then went through a free for all period where the pioneers try different methodologies out and map out the basic structure of the field and the identify the problems to solve. Then things settle down and become more defined and organized and productive, massive paradigm shifts notwithstanding. 2.      Second, it is a human science, so there is all the complication of human systems being complex dynamical systems with often chaotic, unpredictable dynamics, and as well, there is the issue that humans, so far as we can see, have free will, making the system not completely deterministic. 3.      Third, there is the sweeping scope of economics. One possible definition of economics could be “The study of how humans use technology to manage limited resources and organize their activity to raise their relative standard of living.” (Here technology is used in the abstract academic sense that includes tools, techniques, and processes) When you think about it this way, it touches on almost everything. It’s by nature multidisciplinary – science, technology, information sciences, mathematics, sociology, psychology, education.

According to Karl Popper, the test if something is "science" is that it must be  falsifiable. This means there must be a way to disprove claims made about how some aspect of the universe works. The fact that economics, along with psychology and sociology, makes claims about aspects of human nature, is less a reason to disqualify it from being a science than a reason to despair that human nature is really difficult to model. All science requires that problems be modeled, or simplified, down to a few salient elements. In this light, economics is much, much more difficult to falsify than say, classical harmonics. This is also why though, game theory, networks, and heuristics (more broadly, decision sciences) are currently the most intensely researched/lauded areas in economics and the other social sciences. Providing a stochastic (probabilistic) basis for the  assumptions that economic models make about how and why humans allocate scarce resources is like finding a reason why gravity works everywhere in the universe the same way.
